issues.description: The problem statement (UML and task description) specifies addGuestStudents(int) as a void method (no return value). The reference solution implements addGuestStudents(int) to return a boolean indicating success and performs input validation (returns true/false). This is a signature/return-type mismatch: students following the problem statement will implement a void method, while the solution uses a boolean return type. This inconsistency can confuse students about the expected API and may lead to failing comparisons against the reference implementation or unexpected test behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signature consistent across artifacts. Option A (preferable to match the UML/problem): change the solution's method to `public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents)` and perform validation without returning a value (e.g., ignore negative input or throw an exception if desired). Option B: if you want the method to report success, update the problem statement and UML to declare `addGuestStudents(int): boolean` and document the boolean semantics (true on success, false on invalid input). Apply the chosen signature consistently in the template, problem statement (text and UML), and solution.
